comments.text:
Did you try that on a calculator? What happened is that it took 5! and made 
it negative; try (-5)!. You might think, "Well, it's just -5 × -4 × -3 × -2 
× -1," which is -120. By that logic, -6! would be +720. That procedure 
doesn't seem to truly reflect how factorials work though since their 
extendability all boils down to the relation (n - 1)! = n! ÷ n.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factorial#Non-extendability_to_negative_integers
Because (-1)! = (0 - 1)! = 0! ÷ 0, which is a division by zero, all of the 
other negative integers are undefined. (-2)! = (-1 - 1)! = (-1)! ÷ (-1) is 
undefined because the dividend (-1)! is, as we've just seen, a division by 
zero; (-3)! = (-2 - 1)! = (-2)! ÷ (-2) is undefined because the dividend 
(-2)! is (-1)! ÷ (-1), whose dividend is a division by zero. : D
(Although you could argue that factorials of negative integers *are* 
defined as complex infinity, but that's out of my league.)

comments.text:
+Oats Carter As I said, he was giving motivation for the definition.  The 
reasons he talks about (such as making the patterns continue and the number 
of ways to arrange 0 objects) are reasons why mathematicians decided to 
define 0! = 1.  It's a good definition and it makes things line up very 
nicely, but it is, in fact, a definition.

Notice, he didn't actually *prove* that 0! = 1.  And you *can't* prove that 
0! = 1 unless you've already established the equivalent notion of the empty 
product being 1.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empty_product

Notice that wikipedia says that the empty product is a convention.  And 
that's true.  It is a great convention which greatly simplifies many, many 
things.  But it is, nevertheless, a convention.

+Victor Perkins The factorial of a number n is the product of all integers 
from n down to 1. The lowest number for which this can work is 1. 0 does 
not work for the same reason that all the negative numbers don't work - you 
can't count down from 0 to 1. 0 is the place where it goes wrong. You could 
just about make an argument for the answer being zero, as the first number 
you multiply is zero, but that is it.

destroy spacecraft.

top_comment.text:
For all the people unsatisfied with the explanations offered by the video, 
how about we just rely on the base definition of the factorial? The 
factorial of a non-negative integer n (n!) is defined as the product of all 
positive integers less than or equal to n. There are no positive integers 
less than or equal to 0, so 0! is the empty product, or the product of no 
numbers. The empty product is defined to be the multiplicative identity, 
which is 1. (Just like the empty sum is the additive identity, which is 0).﻿

The point is, that 0!=1 means that multiplying by it doesn`t change 
anything.



Do you know the binomialcoefficient?
It tells you how many ways there are to choose k objects out of n objects.
There are n!/(k!*(n-k)!) ways.
Imagine you would choose 1 object of the n objects. There would be n ways 
to do so.
n!/(1!*(n-1)!)=n

Now imagine you would choose any object, so k=n.
There obviously is only one way to do so. (The order in which you choose is 
irrelevant).
n!/(n!*0!)=1
0! HAS to be 1.
Otherwise the equotation had no solution and it would not be possible to 
choose n out of n objects.

Same for k=0.
n!/(0!*n!)=1           =>0!=1
Otherwise there was no way not to choose any object.

That is why 0!=1 makes sense in math.
It has to be an "empty product".

To subtraction and addition 0 is the number that changes nothing. To 
multiplication 1 is the number that changes nothing.
So in a strange way 0!=1 does probably mean what you understand when you 
think of 0!=0.


The point is, that 0!=1 means that it is not possible to change the 
arrangement of 0 objects.

You guys are overthinking this. Let's look at it another way. What are the 
possible subsets you can have when you arrange N number of objects? Look at 
2. I have 2 objects, 1 and 2. I can arrange them in the following ways: {1, 
2} or {2, 1}. Thus, I can arrange 2 objects in 2 ways, or there are 2 
subsets. When I have 0 objects, I have one subset. {}. This is called an 
empty set. It means it has no values. This is considered the only 
"arrangement" of 0 objects. In this type of statistics, an arrangement is 
the same as a subset. Does that help?

+Subarashi!
 The reason 0! = 1 is well defined. n! is defined as the product of all 
numbers from 1 upwards to n (or from n downwards to 1, doesn't matter). 
Thus 0! doesn't have any elements because from 0 there are no numbers 
downwards to 1.

Thus 0! is the empty product. The empty product (a product with no factors) 
is defined to be equal to the multiplicative identity, which is 1 
(multiplicative identity means you can multiply any number a with it and 
the result is a (a*1=a))

+Subarashi! "10x10 3.141592653589etc" explain how you would get a 
meaningful answer from this. Also how do you multiply something by itself 
part of a time? 

As for factorial, you're missing the point. You're focusing too much on the 
naive interpretation. All that the factorial is is a function for which 

f(n) = nf(n-1) 

f(0) = 1 

or if you'd like, 

f(1) = 1 

for whole numbers. Note how either of those definitions leads to 0! = 1. I 
also think it's worth pointing out that I misread your comment initially 
and thought you were talking about non-integer arguments for factorials. In 
that case, we use the gamma function. However, the gamma function is 
undefined for all negative integers. If we use the gamma function, the 
factorial of zero is undefined. However, due to the recursive definition of 
the factorial function, 0! is usually just accepted to be 1.

comments.text:
When you get to an undefined result, it doesn't necessarily mean that's the 
definitive result.
Sometimes when developing general formulas you realize that, in some cases, 
your formula gives 0/0 as a result, or other ugly things. Then you redo 
your formula making certain assumptions and you get to another formula that 
actually works for those cases, and gives sensible results.
In this case, there's a clear way to get a sensible result for 0!, and that 
is the following:
1! = 1 * (1-1)!
1 = 1 * 0!
1 = 0!
This is completely correct, and 1 is a result that doesn't contradict 
0*(-1)!, because (-1)! is infinity, and 0*infinity can be anything (like 
0/0).
Trust me, this is correct, and it makes a lot of sense for 0! to be 1.

comments.text:
1. These aren't proofs.  0! = 1 is true by convention.  Here, he is giving 
motivation and reasons why 0! = 1 is a good convention.

2. He defines n! at 0:27.  The formula n! = (n+1)!/(n+1) is not a 
definition (and he never calls it a definition either), but a formula that 
can be proven to be true based on the definition he gives at 0:27. 

3. While this video doesn't give an example of this, you can define things 
inductively.  For example, look at the Fibonacci sequence.  We define x(1) 
= 1, x(2) = 1, and then define x(n+2) = x(n+1) + x(n) for all natural 
numbers n.  Here, we're defining terms of the sequence based off of other 
terms of the sequence, but because of the way we're doing it, it's 
perfectly well defined.

If he wanted to, he could have defined 1! = 1, and then (n+1)! = (n+1) * n! 
for all natural numbers n.

Even though he would be using factorial in his definition of factorial, it 
is perfectly valid, since there is no ambiguity whatsoever, as we have been 
given the base case and how to derive high factorials from lower ones.

comments.text:
The flaw in his thinking is evident in one of his first sentences: He says, 
"Let's start off with a quick recap if what a factorial is...." and then 
talks about multiplying all the whole numbers less than or equal to n. The 
next several minutes take a circuitous route to proving 0! = 1 by recursion.

Finally, he talks about permutations of n objects. 

There is a crucial distinction in mathematics between "x is y" and "x is 
equal to y" that gets blurred far too often. n! *is equal to* Πi=1..n Ni 
for i > 0, but that doesn't mean that n! *is* Πi=1..n i. Indeed, the 
question of why 0! = 1 is confusing is because people want to take the fact 
that n! *happens to equal* Πi=1..n i for i > 0 (which is a mathematically 
useful fact) as the *definition* of factorial.

The *definition* of factorial is precisely what he eventually says: It's 
the number of ways that you can arrange n objects in distinct ways. You 
can't arrange a negative, fractional, or non-real number of objects, so n! 
only makes sense for members of N^0. It happens that, for all members of 
N^+, n! = Πi=1..n i, so it's easiest to remember that formula and keep in 
mind that 0! = 1.

+oguzcan nallidere as I said, you *have* the option of picking no flavor, 
but that indeed is arguable.
There's one proof, and that is the Pascal's triangle. It works like this:
The rows represent a number of flavors, and any number in that row is a 
number of combinations of those flavors. So let's say we have 5 objects. 
This corresponds to the 6th row of the triangle: 1 5 10 10 5 1
So:
1 way to pick 5 flavors out of 5
5 ways to pick 4 flavors out of 5
10 ways to pick 3 flavors out of 5
10 ways to pick 2 flavors out of 5
5 ways to pick 1 flavor out of 5
*1 way to pick 0 flavors out of 5*

comments.text:
+Swag Lord Since you're in calc 2 I assumed you already knew integration by 
parts. Basically it's the reverse of the product rule. 

Think about the product rule using Leibniz notation -

d(uv)/dx = u(dv/dx) + v(du/dx)

multiply everything by the differential dx (don't worry we can do this 
because we're treating it as a differential) 

d(uv) = udv + vdu

integrate everything

 uv = integral(udv) +integral(vdu)

manipulate to get 

integral(udv) = uv - integral(vdu) 

And in Lagrange's notation 

integral(f(x)g'(x)dx) = f(x)g(x) - integral(f'(x)g(x)dx)

What this means is that you can use this formula to find integrals of 
functions that can be expressed as the product of a function that is easy 
to differentiate and a function that is easy to integrate. In the case of 
the gamma function, t^2 is easy to differentiate and e^-x is easy to 
integrate. What it comes out to is it says that gamma(t+1) =(t+1)gamma(t) 
and that gamma(0)=1 (recall that the gamma function is the same as (t+1)! 
for natural numbers) which are all you need to define the factorial 
function recursively.

comments.text:
There is no relation between the two part of your sentence. 1! =/= 0 does 
in no way means that 0! is =/= from 1. Or could you explain your reasoning 
further?

The general idea is that n! = n*(n-1)! which means that if n = 1 and 1! = 
1, 1! = 1*0! which implies 0! = 1.Of course it has to stop somewhere, you 
cannot continue until n-1 = minus infinity so there's two solutions:

1) 0! doesn't exist and the formula is wrong for 0 because it only start at 
1
2) 0! does exist and the formula is actually wrong for -1 because it only 
start at 0

The second one is the more consistent one, because if you decide to extend 
the definition to 0, it actually make mathematical sense, but if you try to 
extend it to -1 you obtain a division by 0. You have to understand that 
factorial numbers (or any group of numbers) are an artificial construct. 
We, humans, decide which numbers are or aren't a factorial according to 
what properties are interesting to us.Since 0! respect all the interesting 
properties without breaking mathematics, why not include it?

comments.text:
Your calculator probably also gives you that -2^2 = -4 (Google does too).

This is because of how your phone and your calculator/Google handle inputs.

Your calculator and Google give factorial a higher priority than 
multiplication, meaning that when you type in "-1!" they are taking 1! and 
then multiplying it by -1, which explains why you get -1 (the same thing 
happens with -2^2, they do 2^2 = 4 and then multiply it with -1 to get -4).

Your computer and ipod probably calculate things as you're inputting 
information.  So if you type in "-1!" in that order into your computer, it 
will first calculate -1 and then take the factorial of -1, which doesn't 
exist.  This can cause some trouble with order of operations.  (Try also 
doing "-2^2" on these calculators!)

The difference is that your computer and ipod do calculations as you're 
still inputing things, but Google and your scientific calculator wait until 
you actually tell them to calculate before doing a calculation.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
Well, if you look at the Boltzmann's Principle, which states how many 
possible microstates occur at a certain entropy (this is mostly 
thermodynamics), then you'll find that when there's nothing there-> Entropy 
being zero, the number of possible micro-states is 1. 

This is found from the following equation: S = Kb*ln(gamma) where S is 
entropy, Kb is Boltzmann's constant, and gamma is the # of possible 
micro-states. 

Isolating for gamma gives: gamma = exp(S/Kb) and when S is zero, that makes 
the equation: gamma = exp(0) and any number raised to zero is just 1.

comments.text:
+22NightWing  Challenge accepted, I'll not be looking anything up for this 
so lets hope I'm not too rusty. Note that this definition is relevant 
because we can look at permutations from the opposite perspective: A set 
has N! permutations, each one a unique state. Suppose some set exists. Then 
the set must be in some initial state. The total number of permutations is 
equal to the initial state plus every possible rearrangement of that state.
The definition of a rearrangement can be expressed as follows:

Suppose there exists some set of real numbers E, with X number of elements 
labeled E(1), E(2)... E(X-1), E(X).

Suppose there also exists B, a set of Y real numbers labeled B(1), B(2)... 
B(Y-1), B(Y).

Then B is defined as a rearrangement of A, and visa versa, if and only if 
the following holds
true:

1. E = B (Two sets are defined as equal if and only if every element of one 
set is an element of the other).

2. There exists at least one pair of positive integers N, Q such that:

I. N <= X (N is less than or equal to X)
II.Q <= Y (Q is less than or equal to Y)
III.N != Q (N is not equal to Q)
|V. E(N) = B(Q) (Element N in E is equal to element Q in B. Because a set 
cannot have duplicates, this means that when combined with the previous two 
facts, the following equivalent statement can be made: There exists an 
Integer in E that isn't at the same location in B, meaning they are in 
different orders).
comments.author: Skye Wingpop

comments.text:
+Astro herbs I'm not really sure how Occam's Razor applies to this.  What 
assumption does 0! = 1 make that 0! = 0 does not?

I don't know if there's any immediate direct application of 0! in nature 
(besides the coin example).  But there are applications of the formulas 
which include factorials.

For example, the formula for a combination.  The formula nCk is given by 
n!/(k!(n-k)!).

If you want, you can go out and perform tests on this formula.  For fun, 
let's say you there are 5 cookies on the table (let's say each cookie is a 
different type).  And you are allowed to take 2.  How many possible 
combinations of cookies can you get?

Well, the formula says 5!/(2!(5-2)!) = 5!/(2!3!) = 10.  And if you were to 
actually get 5 different cookies, and count how many combinations of 2 
cookies there are.  And I encourage you to actually model this and see if 
there are in fact 10 combinations of 2 cookies from a collection of 5 
(spoilers: there are).

Now, what if there are 5 cookies on the table, and you are allowed to take 
5 cookies?  Clearly, there's only one combination of 5 cookies you can take 
from a group of 5 cookies.

The formula gives 5!/(5!(5-5)!).  Simplifying this (cancelling the 5!), we 
obtain 1/0!.

This is an instance where we *weren't* plugging 0 into a formula.  We were 
plugging 5 into a formula.  A formula that works in all other instances. 
 But here, we obtain 1/0!.  And we know the actual value for the situation 
is 1.  The only number that 0! could possibly be (if it is a number at all) 
*must* be 1.

Well, yes, we *could* say that the formula works unless n=k.  But then in 
so many formulas, we'll need to specify all these rules and exceptions for 
0! (the binomial formula requires both 0! = 1 and 0^0 = 1, for example).

That being said, I'm not so sure Occam's Razor really helps you here.  0! = 
0 requires just as many assumptions as 0! = 1, but 0! = 0 includes the 
added benefit of making everything more complicated and less elegant. 
 Hmmm... I wonder what Occam's Razor says about that...

Why is not being able to divide by 0 contradictory?  I don't see it.

comments.text:
Yes, it is definitely a philosophical question.  And in the end, this video 
is motivating a definition.  Mathematicians could have chosen to define 0! 
as 0.  However, there are many reasons to define 0! as 1.

As said above, the number of ways to arrange zero objects can be thought of 
as 1.  This is a philosophical argument, to be sure.  But in mathematics, 
"nothing" is something.  Examples of nothing being something include 0 
being a number and the empty set being a set.  Mathematics is a much more 
beautiful theory with much greater explanatory power if we allow nothing to 
be considered as something.

Another reason is utility.  There are many situations (such as power 
series), where factorials show up.  If 0! were 0, we would not be able to 
use the same formulas for many of our power series.  We'd have to write the 
first term separately and then use the formula for the other terms.

It's kind of funny that an Einstein quotation would be brought up about 
this, as Einstein was all about making notation easier to write.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Einstein_notation

Since Einstein found it too cumbersome to even write the sigma for a 
summation, I think he would find it far too cumbersome to write out the 
first term of a power series (or some other series) separately from the 
rest and then use the formula for the others.

But I don't find appealing to Einstein to be the most convincing arguments 
about mathematics.

arrange 0 coins on a table, doesn't that imply that there is always at 
least one coin on the table?

If there's no possible way to have nothing, then there's always something. 
 But we know that we can have no coins on a table, so the claim that it 
must be 0 doesn't make sense.

We know we can have no coins on a table, so there must be at least 1 way to 
have no coins on a table.  But every way of having no coins on a table 
looks exactly the same, so there is at most 1 way to have no coins on a 
table.

Therefore, there is exactly 1 way to have 0 coins on a table, meaning there 
must be 1 way to arrange 0 objects.
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
Because of how math is defined.

a^0 is the empty product (the product of no numbers) which is simply 
defined as the multiplicative identity, which is 1.
And in the same way 0! is the empty product, too.
(In case you don't know: the multiplicative identity is a number by which  
you can multiply any number a and get a back (aka: a*1 = a), similarly the 
additive identity is 0 because a+0 = a)

comments.text:
Anyone who reads this who is struggling with the "arranging zero objects" 
issue, I've replied to a few of you but for those of you who still don't 
quite get it: Throw the arrangement analogy out the window and think of 
what the factorial does in a different way. Let's say that it tells us the 
number of states a system can be in with n number of objects. So a system 
of 3 objects, so 3!, can have 6 possible states to be in. 3! = 6. There are 
6 ways to order the coins so 6 states. A system with 2 objects can only 
have 2 possible states. 2! = 2. Now for a system with 0 objects, let's say 
an empty room or empty box, even tho you cannot arrange anything in that 
box, it is still in a state of being. The box is empty, that is it's state. 
Therefore 0! = 1. Don't think of the factorial as a simple straightforward 
math problem, understand what it's doing by nature and it should be easy to 
understand why it is equal to 1.
comments.author: t3hPoundcake

You will need 2 proofs to understand it:
First, the definition of an empty product is the multiplicative identity, 
which is 1.

(I'm sure you can research the proofs that an empty product = 1)

We can define n! as the product of all the natural numbers less than n+1.
for example,
4! = 4 * 3 * 2 * 1

then,
3! = 3 * 2 * 1 = 6.
2! = 2 * 1
1! = 1
0! =(empty product)

an empty product, by definition, is a multiplicative identity, which is 1.

(This would also suggest, though, that  the factorial of -1 (and all 
negative numbers for that matter) is equal to 1, because they would all be 
empty products as well.
comments.author: Brandon Kekahuna

comments.text:
ok: The factorial is defined(!) recursively via n!=n*(n-1)! - this 
Definition only makes sense if you have a (smallest) starting point. So 
either you have to pick as starting point 1!=1, in which case 0! isn't even 
defined, or you have 1!=1*(1-1)!=1*0! and thus 0!=1.

For the same reason the "empty product" is also defined as 1: If I have a 
sequence of number a_0,a_1,a_2,... and I want to multiply the first n of 
them, I can write (product from i=0 to n over a_i). This is usually denoted 
by a big pi with i=0 underneath, n above it and a_i afterwards, similar to 
the sum-symbol. Then obviously (product from i=0 to n+m over a_i) is the 
same as (product from i=0 to n over a_i) * (product from i=n+1 to n+m over 
a_i), i.e. I can "spilt the product" anywhere. But then I should also be 
able to write (product from i=0 to n over a_i)=(product from i=0 to n+0 
over a_i)=(product from i=0 to n over a_i) * (product from i=n+1 to n+0 
over a_i) whereas the last product is "empty". Then for the whole equation 
to make any sense at all, the last product HAS to be 1.

Then of course the factorial can be defined as (product from i=1 to n over 
i) and thus 0!=(product from i=1 to 0 over i) is the empty product, which 
is equal to 1.
comments.author: Dennis Müller

comments.text:
Another way to explain it (kind of like the coin version) is this:
You are at a burger stand.  There are, say, seven different toppings you 
can have in your burger.  If you want all 7, how many different ways can 
you make your burger?  E.g. you can put #1, then #6, and so on.  Or you 
could do #7 first, then #4.  Like that.
You will find that the answer is 7!.  You have 7 options for your first 
topping, 6 for your second one, etc.
So it follows that with 6 toppings available, you have 6! different 
permutations.  For 5, you have 5!, for 4 you have 4! options, for 3 there 
are 3!, for 2 there are 2!, and if there is only one topping, there is only 
1! = 1 way.
Now with 0 toppings…
Well, there is still 1 way to have an empty burger bun!
So 0! = 1.
Credit for this proof goes to the wonderful and amazing Kjartan Poskitt.  I 
re-phrased the proof from his books/website.

comments.text:
Yeah, I get what you're saying. It doesn't really make sense when you think 
about division. However, here's a more concrete explanation of why 0! = 1. 

We know that there are n! ways to arrange n distinct objects. We'll use 
this fact later.

So, let's say you have n objects, but you only want to arrange r of them. 
How many ways are there to do that? It turns out the answer, which is 
another widely-used formula, is n! / (n - r)!.

To see this, say we have 7 objects and are arranging 3 of them. For the 
first object, we have 7 choices. For the second, we have 6 choices, and for 
the third, we have 5 choices. Therefore, there are 7x6x5 ways to arrange 3 
objects from a group of 7. This is equal to 7! / 4! because of the 
cancelling and stuff.

So, when r is a positive integer less than or equal to n, there are n! / (n 
- r)! ways to arrange those r objects. 

What happens when r = n? Then the question is, we have n objects, and how 
many ways are there to arrange all n of them? According to the formula, 
there are n! / (n - n)! = n! / 0! ways to do so.

But we already know the answer. There are n! ways to arrange n objects. 
Therefore:

n! / 0! = n!

Hence, 0! must be equal to 1. It can't be equal to any other number. It 
also can't be undefined due to that equality.

comments.text:
Hello!  I don't know if my reply will be very helpful, but I can try.

0. t is a dummy variable.  It's what you're integrating with respect to. 
 James Grime made a mistake when writing up the gamma function, so it 
should say "e^-t dt NOT e^-n dn" (as the description of the video points 
out).

1. Okay, so a function is holomorphic if it is complex differentiable. 
 This means, you can take its derivative in the complex plane.  Holomorphic 
is an equivalent condition to being analytic.  Analytic means that a power 
series representation of the function exists.  Complex differentiability is 
a really strict condition, actually.  But functions which are holomorphic 
(analytic), have extremely nice properties (and it turns out that most 
functions we care about are holomorphic - polynomials, exponential 
functions, trig functions, logarithmic functions, nth root functions.)

The gamma function is... not quite holomorphic.  It's the next best thing 
to being holomorphic.  The gamma function is what you would call 
"meromorphic."  So, what does "meromorphic" mean?  A function F(z) is 
meromorphic if it is holomorphic everywhere except a few isolated points. 
 So the complex derivative of the gamma function exists except at a 
collection of isolated points, in this case, the negative integers.  We 
call these places "poles" (pole has a technical meaning, and is a special 
type of singularity, but it turns out that meromorphic functions have poles 
where their complex derivative does not exist).  It turns out that the 
function is undefined where it has poles and is defined everywhere else.

2. Yes, in fact, what I was talking about in number 1 was actually the 
"analytic continuation" of the gamma function.  It doesn't even really make 
sense to talk about an analytic function unless it is complex-valued to 
begin with.  But yes, we can extend the gamma function to the complex 
plane.  So the gamma function is defined for all complex numbers, except at 
its poles, the negative integers.

3. Yes and no.  In 2, I said that the gamma function has an "analytic 
continuation."  Technically, this is not true.  Rather, it has a 
"meromorphic" continuation, which just means that the gamma function can be 
extended to a meromorphic function on the complex plane.  A lot of people 
will call it an analytic continuation, which is technically incorrect, but 
not a big deal, since we generally understand what is meant.  By 
definition, though, an analytic continuation is, in fact, an extension of a 
function to the complex plane so that the function is analytic/holomorphic.

4. The meromorphic continuation of the gamma function cannot handle 
negative integers, but can handle all other complex numbers, including 
negative real numbers which are not integers.  Since the gamma function has 
poles at the negative integers, some people work in the extended complex 
numbers and say that the value of the gamma function at a negative integer 
is "complex infinity."  In fact, if you use WolframAlpha and type in 
"gamma(-1)", it will spit out complex infinity as the answer.

Your questions all deal with a branch of mathematics called "Complex 
Analysis."  It is a very advanced mathematics courses (some math majors 
take it as undergrads, but many don't see it until grad school!), so if 
this seems confusing, don't feel bad.  There's a lot of weird terminology, 
and it is really difficult to follow the terminology unless you actually 
study the subject.

top_comment.text: What's the inverse function of factorial?﻿
top_comment.author: Gruntay Merkul

comments.text: Derivatives
comments.author: Stephan van Ingen

comments.text:
For sets X and Y, a function f from X into Y is a subset of the Cartesian 
Product of X and Y such that for every x in X, there exists a y in Y such 
that (x, y) is in f and if (x, y) and (x, z) are both in f then y = z.  To 
create an inverse function, you flip the terms in the ordered pairs, so 
each (x, y) becomes (y, x) in the inverse function.  However, for a 
function to have an inverse, it must be both one-to-one and onto. 
 One-to-one means that if (x, y) and (z, y) are both in f, then x = z. 
 Onto means that the codomain of f is equal to the range of f. 
 Colloquially, this means that every member of the set Y is in at least one 
of the ordered pairs in f.  So for the basic definition of factorial, If X 
is the set of all non-negative integers, and Y is exactly the set of all 
numbers which result when you apply factorial to all members of X, then the 
function would have an inverse...otherwise not.  So specifically a mapping 
of non-negative integers into non-negative integers would not have an 
inverse.  I'm not sure what the result is when both X and Y are the set of 
non-negative real numbers.  Some math guy would know the answer, or could 
solve it easily from the equation in the video...I'm not really a math guy.

top_comment.text:
This video irks me as a mathematician: it obfuscates. Insights:
1. 0 is not in the domain of n! with its intensional definition as the 
product 1*2*...*n. This leaves 0! undefined.
2. We can extend n! and define a new function in any way we like. Setting 
0!=316 is perfectly legal.
3. Most extensions are not productive, but one preserving an important 
property like n!=n*(n-1)! is. (wiki Gamma function).
Prove a nice theorem with a different extension of n! and mathematicians 
will be delighted.:)﻿

comments.text:
+Arkalius80
I do not mean to be harsh, but you seem to be missing the point that it's 
all about definition vs. proof. Conflating them is unsound, both 
didactically and mathematically. I'm fine with it if you wish to use a 
definition which entails 0!=1 immediately. But Grime does not mention the 
empty product convention, and you cannot deduce 0!=1 from the value set {n! 
: n=1,2,...} alone.
comments.author: Maxim Hendriks

comments.text:
+Maxim Hendriks Except your definition is incomplete. Mine is not, and 
includes 0! without doing anything wacky or hard to follow. It's also the 
definition listed on Wikipedia. It's also consistent with the Gamma 
function which is defined for 1 (equivalent to 0!).
comments.author: Arkalius80

comments.text:
+Arkalius80
Of course the empty product *convention* (definition) is the most or even 
only sensible one, and you can *add* it to the definition of n! to get a 
value for 0!. But again it does not follow from the basic definition of the 
factorial (as in my item 1. above), i.e. you cannot prove it from only this 
definition. The whole conflation of proof with definition is what troubles 
me in a video that tries to teach some math.
comments.author: Maxim Hendriks

comments.text:
The factorial is defined for all non-negative integers n as the product of 
all positive integers less than or equal to n. Since there are none with 
n=0, it is the empty product, 1.
